Award.AwardTitle: MRI-R2: Acquisition of an XRD, Raman Spectrometer and Sorption Analyzer for the Creation of a Materials Characterization CyberLab
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award is funded under the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 (Public Law 111-5).

With this award from the Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) program Professor Rolando M. Roque-Malherbe and colleagues José Duconge, César Lozano, Francisco Marquez-Linares and Agustín Ríos from the School of Science at Universidad Del Turabo will acquire a powder X-ray diffractometer that will also be utilized by scientists from the Department of Chemistry and Physics as well as the Institute of Physical Chemical Applied Research. The instrument will be used to support research activities and education programs in the synthesis, characterization and properties of new or modified zeolites, silica, molecular organic frameworks, carbon nanotubes, porous anodic materials, semiconductor and metallic nanostructured catalysts, proton conducting and oxygen permeable perovskites.

An X-ray diffractometer allows accurate and precise measurements of the full three dimensional structure of a molecule, including bond distances and angles, and provides accurate information about the spatial arrangement of a molecule relative to neighboring molecules. A powder diffractometer allows diffraction studies and analysis of powdered crystalline materials. The studies described here will impact a number of areas, including chemistry, materials chemistry, and geology. This instrument will be an integral part of teaching as well as research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The funds were provided for the acquisition of a Brüker D8 Advance, X-ray diffraction-small angle X-ray scattering facility, with it: about one hundred metal organic frameworks (MOFs) were characterized, between them, three new MOFs structures were refined using the TOPAS software, as well acquired with funds provided by the NSF-MRI-R2 project; additionally, five different akaganeites were investigated, from these, one new magnetic and thermally stable material was found; further, around fifty cyanometalates were collected, from this one new Cu-nitroprusside thermally stable polymorph was discovered; furthermore, the gate opening effect in calcium and magnesium hexacyanoferrates and the framework expansion of the cooper-succinic-MOF were discovered; besides, a new proton conduction mechanism in perovskites was proposed; in addition, transition metal and iron oxide nanoparticles-carbon nanotubes (CNT) composites, and CuO nanorods were investigated for energy and environmental catalysis; furthermore, drug carrier hollow iron oxide were researched; moreover, silicon, iron and palladium nanowires, vertically aligned CNT and as well anodic membranes were researched for different applications. These efforts resulted in the publications of fifteen articles in peer reviewed journals, twenty one presentations in international conferences, furthermore, two PhD and two MS students defended their thesis using data collected with the D8 Advance facility, and ca. 50 students and faculty were trained in the use of this facility.
